definition: double-edged sword/CL:口[kou3],把[ba3]/classifier for blows of a sword

sentences.english: This new freedom is a double-edged sword, however.
sentences.chinese: 然而，语言选择的自由是把双刃剑。

sentences.english: A new CEO may be more receptive, but time is a double-edge sword.
sentences.chinese: 新CEO可能更加包容，但时间是把双刃剑。

sentences.english: "Memory is a double-edged sword," Hills says.
sentences.chinese: “记忆力是把双刃剑，”希尔斯说。

sentences.english: Modern information technology is just like a two-side sword to enterprises.
sentences.chinese: 现代信息和网络技术就像一把双刃剑。

sentences.english: The Internet is just like a double-edged sword.
sentences.chinese: 互联网就像一把双刃剑。

sentences.english: But consumption, for people of faith, is a double-edged sword.
sentences.chinese: 但对自由市场的信仰者而言，消费是把双刃剑。

sentences.english: Taijijian (literally "Taiji Sword") is a straight two-edged sword used in the training of the Chinese martial art Taijiquan.
sentences.chinese: 太极剑是笔直的双刃剑，用于中国武术太极拳训练。

sentences.english: The imagination is a double-edged sword.
sentences.chinese: 我们的想象力就是这样一把双刃剑。

sentences.english: Workplace friendships are like a double-edged sword.
sentences.chinese: 职场友谊就像一把双刃剑。

sentences.english: Szymanski starts from the premise that the P-word is a double-edged sword.
sentences.chinese: 西曼斯基首先提出，完美主义是一把双刃剑。

sentences.english: Heritage tourism development was a double-edged sword.
sentences.chinese: 文化遗产地的旅游开发是一把双刃剑。

sentences.english: Computer can be a two-edged sword.
I think that any system is a double-edged sword.
sentences.chinese: 任何一种制度都是一把双刃剑，有利有弊。

sentences.english: Nonetheless, it is also a double-edged blade: dehumanizing our society.
sentences.chinese: 虽然如此，它依然是把双刃剑。

sentences.english: This is a sort of two-way changing like a double-edged sword.
sentences.chinese: 这是一种双向的变化，就像一把双刃剑。

definition: lit. drinking poison in the hope of quenching one's thirst (idiom)/fig. a supposed remedy that only makes matters worse
too far is as bad as not enough (idiom, from the Analects)
see 未可厚非[wei4 ke3 hou4 fei1]
lit. severe floods and fierce beasts (idiom)/fig. great scourges/extremely dangerous or threatening things
lit. one body two sides (idiom)/fig. a situation with two sides to it
to regard as/to look upon as
